questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with diminished hearing on the right side. The symptoms have been present for one week but worsened acutely the morning of presentation, after she removed foam ear plugs from her ear canals. She also complains of aural fullness, tinnitus, and a sense of disequilibrium.
On otoscopic examination, the patient is found to have a small amount of moist, keratinized debris in the lateral canal and cerumen obstructing view of the tympanic membrane. On tuning-fork examination, the Weber test lateralizes to the right. Attempted removal of the cerumen with a plastic cerumen loop causes pain.
Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Irrigate the ear canal with cold water
Remove debris with a cotton-tipped applicator

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Irrigation may also be performed, but cold water should not be used because it can induce a caloric-reflex response, resulting in nystagmus.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical neomycin/polymyxin is used to treat otitis externa. Although it will soften the wax over time and facilitate removal, it is an inappropriate use of an antibiotic.

C) INCORRECT:

Candling is an “alternative” treatment for cerumen impaction that involves inserting the unlit end of hollow lit candle into the ear canal. It should be avoided, as studies show that it does not aid in wax removal and can have serious complications if the hot wax runs into the ear canal.

D) INCORRECT:

A cotton-tipped applicator can be used to remove soft cerumen from the lateral ear canal; however, it should be avoided in cases of impacted cerumen because it can push the impacted wax further into the canal.

E) CORRECT:

Cerumen is a naturally occurring substance that is excreted in the ear canal; it may become impacted in individuals with abnormally shaped ear canals, excessive ear-canal hair, and frequent ear-canal manipulation from hearing aids, cotton-swab use, or ear plugs.

Cerumen impaction is associated with ear discomfort, aural fullness, muffled hearing, and tinnitus. Presentation may be acute if a cerumen plug is pushed against the tympanic membrane. Impacted cerumen may be solid and cause discomfort on attempted removal. If this is the case, cerumenolytics such as docusate sodium, hydrogen peroxide, carbamide peroxide, or mineral oil can be used to soften the cerumen and facilitate removal.

Key learning point: If cerumen cannot be removed using a cerumen loop, attempts should be made using cerumenolytics, irrigation (with water or saline that is at body temperature), or both.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old man with a history of Parkinson disease and stroke is a long-term resident at a subacute nursing facility. During the past several months, he has become progressively more confused, requiring redirection, and appears more withdrawn. He wears hearing aids that appear to be in working order without wax buildup and states that he does not experience tinnitus.
Physical examination reveals paste-like, dark-colored debris in both ears, with more in the right than the left. On tuning fork examination after removal of the hearing aids, the Weber test lateralizes to the right, and the Rinne test is positive (i.e., air conduction is better than bone conduction) bilaterally. His neurologic examination is otherwise normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss that is greater on the right
Chronic serous otitis media that is greater on the left
Presbycusis that is greater on the right

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A right-sided vestibular schwannoma results in a sensorineural hearing loss on the right side, so the Weber test would lateralize to the left.

B) CORRECT:

The Rinne test is performed by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid process until sound is no longer heard. The fork is then immediately placed just outside the ear. In a normal ear, air conduction is better than bone conduction, and the patient can therefore hear the sound again when the tuning fork is moved from the mastoid process (bone) to outside the ear (air); this is known as a positive Rinne test. In conductive hearing loss, bone conduction is better than air conduction, and the sound is therefore heard better with the tuning fork on the mastoid process; this is known as a negative Rinne test. In the Weber test, the tuning fork is placed in the middle of the skull, and the patient determines on which side the sounds can be heard most clearly.

When the conductive hearing loss is mild (less than about 30 db), the Rinne test remains positive and the Weber lateralizes to the side with conductive loss. When the conductive hearing loss is moderate (about 30 db or greater), the Rinne test changes to negative, and the Weber still lateralizes to the side of the conductive loss. Most cases of wax obstruction give a mild conductive loss and do not cause the Rinne test to change to negative.

In this patient, the Weber test lateralizes to the right ear, which could be consistent with either conductive hearing loss on the right or sensorineural hearing loss on the left. Of the answer options provided, the only one that leads to a Weber test lateralizing to the right ear is a conductive hearing loss from cerumen in the right ear.

Cerumen impaction is common, particularly in nursing-home residents, older adults, patients with mental disabilities, and those who use hearing aids. Substantial impaction can lead to conductive hearing loss from impaired mechanical transmission of sound. This may result in decreased cognitive function in vulnerable populations. Loss of hearing leads to a decrease in interaction with others, greater isolation, and cognitive decline. Cerumen should be removed with a curette, cerumenolytics, lavage, or a combination of these methods.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of conductive hearing loss in a nursing-home resident with debris in the ear is cerumen impaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis in the left ear is a cause of conductive hearing loss and causes the Weber test to lateralize to the left.

D) INCORRECT:

Serous otitis media in the left ear (fluid in the middle ear) results in a conductive hearing loss and also lateralizes the Weber test to the left.

E) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis greater in the right ear is functionally similar to sensorineural hearing loss on the right, and again the Weber test would lateralize to the left.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension and stable coronary artery disease presents for routine follow-up. He is accompanied by his daughter, who expresses concern that he has been staying home more often and ignoring phone calls. She notes that during a family reunion last weekend, he appeared to be sad and kept to himself despite looking forward to the event for several months.
The patient says he does not remember his daughter phoning him and that he did not ignore any calls deliberately. He explains that he prefers to be at home to avoid crowded places and says that he had a hard time keeping up with his family members at the reunion, especially those wearing face masks.
Throughout the interview, he appears to have difficulty understanding questions, looks to his daughter multiple times with a confused and embarrassed expression, and asks for questions to be repeated.
His Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-2 score is 0, and his Mini-Cog assessment score is 4 (2 out of 2 on the clock-drawing test and 2 out of 3 on word recall). His general physical and neurologic examinations are normal.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Complete a General Anxiety Disorder-7 questionnaire
Begin a trial of a low-dose antidepressant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening with the General Anxiety Disorder-7 questionnaire is reasonable, but this patient’s inability to maintain conversations with people wearing masks and his history of unintentionally missing calls (likely because he does not hear the phone ring) make hearing impairment a more likely explanation for his behavior changes. Hearing impairment should be considered before a definitive diagnosis of anxiety can be made.

B) INCORRECT:

The most appropriate next step for this patient is to inspect the ear canal with an otoscope for cerumen impaction, a common cause of hearing impairment that is easily identifiable and easily treatable and could interfere with an accurate audiology evaluation. Once otoscopy is performed and any cerumen impaction is treated, an audiology referral would then be appropriate and could identify additional causes of hearing impairment, such as presbycusis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient scored 4 out of 5 on the Mini-Cog assessment. A score of ≥3 has been validated as a negative screen for dementia, but it does not rule out cognitive impairment. Further testing for cognitive impairment with tools such as the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) can be considered in patients with Mini-Cog scores of ≤4. However, this patient should be evaluated for hearing impairment before taking the MoCA because impaired hearing can confound the results. Ensuring that the patient can hear all of the words in the assessment and can demonstrate correct encoding before the clock-drawing task is important. Consonant sounds, such as the “ch-” in “chair,” may be particularly difficult for patients with presbycusis to discern.

D) INCORRECT:

Several elements of this patient’s history are concerning for depression and appropriately prompted administration of the Patient Health Questionnaire-2 (PHQ-2). A PHQ-2 score of ≥3 would warrant further evaluation for depression with the PHQ-9. However, this patient had a PHQ-2 score of 0, making depression less likely, and other conditions should therefore be ruled out before an antidepressant is considered.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s social isolation, missed telephone calls, and difficulty hearing the clinician’s questions suggest possible hearing impairment. Loss of hearing may lead to decreased social interaction and increased isolation and is associated with depression, falls, and cognitive decline.

The most appropriate next step for this patient is to inspect the ear canal with an otoscope for cerumen impaction, a common cause of hearing impairment that is easily identifiable and easily treatable and could interfere with an accurate audiology evaluation. Once otoscopy is performed and any cerumen impaction is treated, an audiology referral would then be appropriate and could identify additional causes of hearing impairment, such as presbycusis. Presbycusis, or age-related hearing loss, typically affects high-frequency hearing and can lead to difficulty in hearing everyday sounds such as conversations, the telephone ringing, road traffic, and music.

Overall, the best next step for this patient is otoscopy to evaluate for possible cerumen impaction. If cerumen is found, effective treatment options include irrigation, cerumenolytic agents, and manual removal with instrumentation. A patient who experiences pain or vertigo during removal, or who undergoes unsuccessful cerumen removal, should be referred to otolaryngology.

Key learning point: Cerumen impaction, a common cause of impaired hearing in older adults, can be diagnosed in the office with otoscopic evaluation of the ear canal. The condition is easily treatable, and treatment sometimes significantly and immediately improves a patient’s hearing impairment.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic ear drops are indicated in otitis externa, which can manifest with symptoms such as ear pain, itching, and hearing loss. However, the absence of otorrhea, severe pain, and typical physical examination findings (e.g., an erythematous and edematous external auditory canal) make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic cerumen accumulation does not require treatment unless a thorough assessment of the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, or audiovestibular apparatus is necessary. This patient does have symptoms, necessitating an intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Referral to an otolaryngologist is appropriate for individuals with risk factors for cerumen removal complications (e.g., nonintact tympanic membrane, risk for infection) or previous unsuccessful attempts at cerumen removal. This patient's uncomplicated cerumen impaction can be managed in a primary care setting.

D) CORRECT:

Cerumen removal is indicated for all individuals with cerumen impaction. Treatment options include manual cerumen removal, ear canal irrigation, and cerumenolytics, used alone or in combination. Cerumen removal is not indicated for asymptomatic cerumen accumulation, except for cases in which a thorough assessment of the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, or audiovestibular apparatus is necessary. While anyone can develop cerumen impaction, it is most common in individuals with risk factors for cerumen impaction, such as regular insertion of objects into the ear canal (e.g., cotton-tipped swabs), anatomical ear abnormalities, dermatological conditions (e.g., eczema, seborrheic dermatosis), and individuals who are unable to recognize or communicate symptoms (i.e., young children, individuals with cognitive impairment, and older adults). Prevention involves patient education on ear hygiene. In individuals with recurrent cerumen impaction, cerumen removal regimens may be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Although olive oil ear drops can soften cerumen, they are generally ineffective for treating cerumen impaction. Ear candling, olive oil drops, cotton-tipped swabs, and at-home use of jet irrigators are not recommended because they are ineffective and can increase the risk of injury. A different management step is more appropriate.
questions.hint: Hearing loss in a patient whose ear canal is obstructed with cerumen is consistent with cerumen impaction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of left ear fullness and decreased hearing. He has a history of chronic otitis media with prior tympanoplasty 8 years ago. Physical examination shows completely impacted cerumen obscuring visualization of the left tympanic membrane. The patient reports no ear pain, fever, or drainage. What is the most appropriate initial management approach?

choices.text: Ear canal irrigation with warm saline solution
Manual cerumen removal with direct visualization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Both irrigation and cerumenolytics are contraindicated in this patient due to his history of tympanoplasty and the inability to verify tympanic membrane integrity.

B) INCORRECT:

Ear canal irrigation is contraindicated in patients with prior ear surgery, including tympanoplasty, due to increased risk of tympanic membrane perforation even when the membrane appears intact. This patient's surgical history creates structural weakness that makes irrigation unsafe.

C) INCORRECT:

While otolaryngology referral is appropriate for complex cerumen impaction (e.g., in patients with risk factors for complications), manual cerumen removal can be safely performed in the ED with direct visualization in patients with prior ear surgery.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Manual cerumen removal with direct visualization is the preferred method for patients with prior ear surgery. This approach allows for controlled, gentle removal while directly visualizing the ear canal and avoiding the risks of irrigation or cerumenolytics in patients with potentially compromised tympanic membrane integrity.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerumenolytic agents are contraindicated when tympanic membrane integrity cannot be verified, which is the case here due to complete cerumen obstruction. Additionally, this patient's history of prior ear surgery increases the risk of membrane perforation, making cerumenolytics inappropriate.
